title: spider spinning web inside mans ear
story: The patient, aged in his s, had gone to his doctor complaining of an itchy crawling sensation in his right ear.Dr Zhang Pan, of the Affiliated Hospital of Yangzhou University in East China’s Jiangsu Province, said he had to use an endoscope to see the bug deep in the canal.But when he tried to grab it with a pair of tweezers, it was too quick and he had to try and flush it out with solution.He said: “I didn’t notice it when inspecting [his ear] with the naked eye.“However, using an endoscope, I discovered the small spider inside.”The patient, who hasnt been named, turned to the ear, nose and throat specialist after complaining of constant itching and a “crawling sensation” in his ear.Video shows Dr Zhang reaching into the patient’s ear with a needle and then filling his ear canal with a few drops of saline.The panicking spider, which appears to have spun a large web covering the entire ear canal, is very quickly driven out by the present of liquid in its otherwise warm and cosy den.Dr Zhang did not say whether they killed the spider or let it live.The medic said the patient avoided any damage to his ear canal because he was quick to seek treatment.He has advised members of the public to seek immediate medical attentionthey find an insect or spider in their ear.Though there are methods to remove the pests - such as using a torch to draw out mosquitoes and moths, or drowning creepy-crawly in oil - the safest way is still to visit a doctor, Dr Zhang added.

title: britains biggest family radfords house morecambe
story: Supermum Sue, , has given their fans a tour of the huge home they share in Morecambe, Lancashire.Sue and Noel, ,  live in a -bedroom former care home, which they bought for £, in .The eldest two children, Chris, , and Sophie, , no longer living at home.Living in the house is Chloe, , Jack, , Daniel, , Luke, , Millie, , Katie, , James, , Ellie,  and Aimee, .The youngest of the brood Josh, , Max, nine, Tillie, eight, Oscar, seven, Casper, six, Hallie, three, Phoebe, two, -month-old Archie, and four-month-old Bonnie are also under the same roof.The ever-growing family makes full use of the space, with several of the children crammed in the same bedrooms.Despite being full to the brim, the home is immaculate and well looked after by stay-at-home mum Sue.When visitors walk through the front door theyree greeted by a giant storage unit that holds all the childrens coats.The hallway is cluttered with the familys stuff, with Sue admitting theres stuff, stuff everywhere.On the ground floor is their cosy living room featuring an enormous leather sofa, fireplace and a toy box full to the brim.Next is the kitchen with a giant fridge, breakfast bar, oven and dishwasher.But Sue isnt a fan of the impressive set up, saying: I hate this kitchen but thankfully its getting ripped out next month, so its all going to be changed.Their dining room has a whopping twelve seats and a highchair around a long table.On this level there is also a small toilet and a huge shoe storage space, which has been expertly organised by Sue.Up the first flight of stairs is the girls room, which is shared by four sisters.Small single beds belonging to Katie, Ellie, Aimee  and Tillie are all lined up in a row.The pretty room is covered in a pink wallpaper with images of the Efel Tower.Next door is the smallest room in the house which contains bunk beds shared by Josh and Max.Also on this floor is Chloes bedroom, which she has all to herself.She has her own double bed and a widescreen TV in the corner.Daniel, Luke and James share two bunk beds - constructed by Noel - in another room.The boys have their own TV and an impressive computer game setup.The kids have their own bathroom on this floor which features stained glass windows left over from the houses care home days.On the top floor is Noel and Sues bedroom, which has a bed with a crushed velvet headboard, dressing table and stylish wooden beams on the ceiling.Another boys room has bunk beds for Oscar, Casper and a crib for Archie in the corner.Hallie and Phoebe share small attic-style room on this floor.There is also a washroom with the houses only bath, which Sue admits causes huge queues.In the hallway of the basement is a treadmill, which Sue jokes her husband bought during a midle crisis.There is a laundry room featuring Sues prized possession: a kg washing machine.She says: I love this washing machine, its amazing. aA you can see its on, its always on.Nine loads of washing are done each day, using  bottles of washing liquid every month and the family uses four toilet rolls per day.The houses only spare bedroom is in the basement, currently being used as a makeup room by Chloe.Millie, , and Jack, , have their own rooms with their own double beds on this floor.In Jacks room he has a games chair and a gaming computer with three screens.Sue and Noel plan to use it as a downstairs lounge when the kids eventually move out.

title: fiona onasanya kicked out as mp for peterborough after lying about speeding ticket
story: The Peterborough politician was booted from her seat after she went to jail for a month., people in her area signed an official petition demanding she leave her £, a year role and a new election be held.The -year-old ex-solicitor can stand again to become their MP as an independent, but is unlikely to succeed after her spell behind bars.Nigel Farage has his eye on the seat and is set to get a Brexit Party candidate to run in the race.He tweeted on Tuesday evening: I can confirm that @brexitparty_uk will fight the Peterborough by-election. We will give it our best shot.Onasanya was kicked out of the Labour Party too - but has insisted shes innocent and refused to quit.Shes the first politician to be kicked out by Parliament under the new recall rules, and the seat will be vacant until the by-election takes place.If she had been jailed for  months then she could have been automatically booted out as an MP.Onasanya was found guilty of perverting the course of justice after she lied about who was driving her car when it was caught speeding in , shortly after she was elected to Parliament.She launched an appeal against her three-month sentence but it failed.Her brother Festus was jailed for  months for her involvement in the incident.Labours Chair Ian Lavery said this evening: Labour campaigned hard for a victory in this recall petition.The people of Peterborough clearly agree that Fiona Onasanya is not fit to be their MP and we’re delighted they will now have the chance to vote for a Labour MP in our excellent candidate, Lisa Forbes.And Tory candidate for the seat, Paul Bristow said this evening: The people of Peterborough deserve a better MP who will vote in Parliament to deliver Brexit.I’m delighted this result gives local people the chance to make their voices heard and vote for a better MP – and it will be a choice between Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour candidate and me.Ukip will battle for the seat too, leader Gerard Batten confirmed.A petition startsan MP has been convicted of an offence , has been barred for the House of Commons for  days, or is convicted for anything to do with expenses.The petition cant open until all the appeals have been exhausted.It is open for six weeks andat least  per cent of the constituency sign it, the MP will lose their seat and a by-election will be called.The booted MP can still stand, however.This is the first time in history an MP has been booted out of their seat.Last year a petition to try and get rid of of the DUPs Ian Paisley failed to get enough support.Next week a petition to unseat Tory MP Chris Davies, who was convicted of fiddling his expenses, will open in the Brecon  Radnorshire seat.

title: venezuela coup maduro surrounded by scorpions bottle john bolton
story: Trump’s national security aide John Bolton says Maduro is surrounded by scorpions in a bottle and its only a matter of time before he’s toppled.Opposition leader Juan Guaid’s has today renewed his attempt to spur a military uprising against Moscow-backed Maduro whose hard left regime has turned South Americas richest country into its poorest.Speaking to reporters outside the White House, Bolton said: “Yesterday even though Maduro didn’t leave the country as he was planning to do because of Russian advice.“The fact is key figures like the defence minister, the chief judge of the supreme court and the head of the presidential guard have been outed as people dealing with the opposition.“And some day the documents they were prepared to sign with the opposition will become public.“Soyou are Nicolas Maduro can you look at your defence minister any more and trust him “I don’t think so. I think Maduro is now surrounded by scorpions in a bottle and it’s only a matter of time.The Cold War era phrase scorpions in a bottle refers to a mutual destruction scenario whereone stings, all end up stung.Bolton used the analogy on Maduros position because it would only take one of his nervous ministers to back-stab him for the whole besieged regime to fall.The veteran National Security Adviser also said US military forces are “ready to go” into the South American nation at a moment’s notice to support the uprising. Speaking earlier on Hugh Hewitt’s radio show, Bolton said: “We’re on the balls of our feet ready to go.”Secretary of State Mike Pompeo also confirmed today that “military action is possible”.The bid to oust the socialist president comes as Venezuela goes into meltdown. Its once prosperous people are angry because while their country has the largest oil reserves in the world, it suffers from chronic food and medicine shortages plus crippling power blackouts. Meanwhile hyper-inflation has rendered their currency and people’s savings worthless.All this has sparked months of demonstrations — but yesterday’s call for an uprising and large scale demonstrations is the most dramatic development so far and suggests a full scale civil war may be imminent. But Maduro is still clinging on to power with backing from his powerful ally, Russian President Vladimir Putin.A second day of protests against the social regime is underway today.State security forces are using tear gas to disperse protesters opposed to President Nicol’s Maduro.They have gathered at a posh El Paraiso neighbourhood in western Caracas where the socialist government elite live, demanding Maduro steps down and a general election is called.  Meanwhile paranoid Maduro and a “dirty dozen” of his top lieutenants are holed-up in a luxurious palace complex.The tyrant has taken refuge in Fort Tiuna surrounded by thousands of CUBAN troops as he no longer trusts his own army with his le.Maduro went into hiding after violence — which saw defecting soldiers stage pitched battles with Maduros military — was sparked by opposition leader Juan Guaidos calls to oust him.Amid the mounting mayhem, armoured cars were filmed driving at full speed into the crowds of people.Horrying video showed demonstrators lying on the ground with their heads and legs bloodied after being mowed down by troops fighting under the orders of Maduro.But the chaos was far removed from the tranquillity of the leaders luxury enclave in Caracas with its bowling alley, swimming pools, lakes and restaurants.Maduro and his henchmen are living in fabulous estates which would not look out of place in the hills of Hollywood.In one area of the complex, next to a military parade ground, a giant iron gate leads into an officers’ club with a bowling alley, floodlit baseball stadium and enormous two-level swimming pool.One visitor to one of the hillside mansions in Fort Tiuna described passing seven checkpoints, the last of which was manned by Cubans in red shirts who supervise Maduro’s security.Confirmation of Maduros five star bolthole was revealed by Donald Trumps National Security Adviser John Bolton.The bloody upheaval in Venezuela saw:In an interview he said: Basically, where they are is a place called Fort Tiuna, which is the Cuban headquarters in Venezuela.Why were they there  Because I think they couldn’t trust most of the Venezuelan forces to actually protect them.The Cubans, they could count on. That tells you what the real political situation in Venezuela is for the regime.Its estimated there are up to , Cuban troops now based in Venzuela tasked with keeping the Maduro alive and his regime in power.Its been reported Venezuelan troops are ready to turn on paranoid Maduro after he cut their monthly pay to just  and infiltrated their ranks with spies.Earlier it was claimed the panicking president was actually ready to flee to Cuba amid yesterdays uprising - and more violent demonstrations are planned today.Pompeo said the besieged tyrant was talked out of boarding a waiting jet at the last minute as an insurrection swept the capital Caracas.Speaking to CNN, Pompeo claimed Maduro was prepared to leave the country on Tuesday as key military and political figures began turning on him in the face of the popular revolt - dubbed Operation Freedom.But Maduro - deemed an illegitimate leader by opponents and many western countries - was talked out of fleeing by Russian backers in the Kremlin, he claimed.Mr Pompeo said: They had an airplane on the tarmac. He was ready to leave this morning, as we understand it.Russians indicated he should stay. He was headed for Havana.The violence - which saw thousands including defecting soldiers take to the streets and mount pitch battles against the loyal military - was sparked after calls by opposition leader Juan Guaido.Amid the mayhem, armoured cars were filmed driving at full speed into the crowd.Horrying video showed demonstrators lying on the ground with their heads and legs bloodied after being mowed down by troops loyal to - and fighting under the orders of - the president.The injured protesters were rushed away on a motorbike as the armoured trucks sped away dodging fireballs thrown by the demonstrators.On Tuesday morning, Guaido told his anti-government supporters to mount a rebellion to overthrow Maduro - who was swept back into power in January following controversial elections deemed illegitimate by many countries.Guaido was joined by Venezuelas most-prominent opposition activist Leopoldo Lopez in a three-minute video to announce the coup yesterday morning.Lopez was apparently released from house arrest by soldiers who defected to the growing anti-government cause and were now answering to Guaido.In the video, Lopez declared: I want to tell the Venezuelan people: This is the moment to take to the streets and accompany these patriotic soldiers.And Guaido said of his defecting military supporters: The armed forces have taken the right decision.With the support of the Venezuelan people and the backing of our constitution they are on the right side of history.The calls kicked off a day of bloody clashes as thousands took to the streets just blocks away from president Maduros presidential palace.The violent street battles that erupted in parts of Caracas were the most serious challenge yet to Maduros rule.While the rebellion seemed to have garnered only limited military support Guaido sought to keep the momentum going at the end of the day by calling for people to take to the streets again today.Yesterday, Guaido and Lopez coordinated actions in the capital from a highway overpass - while troops loyal to Maduro fired tear gas from inside the adjacent air base.A crowd that quickly swelled to a few thousand scurried for cover, reappearing later with Guaido at a plaza a few blocks from the skirmishes.A smaller group of masked youths stayed behind on the highway, lobbing rocks and Molotov cocktails toward the air base and setting a government bus on fire.The head of a medical centre near the site of the street battles said doctors were treating  people, about half of them with injuries suffered from rubber bullets.Venezuelan human rights group Provea said a -year-old man was shot and killed during an anti-government protest in the city of La Victoria.As Maduros forces repelled the action, Lopez and his family sought refuge in the Chilean ambassadors residence in Caracas before moving to the Spanish embassy.Maduro tried to project an image of strength, saying he had spoken to several regional military commanders who reaffirmed their loyalty.He wrote on Twitter: Nerves of steel!But the head of Venezuelas secret police penned a letter breaking ranks with the embattled leader.Manuel Ricardo Cristopher Figuera, the head of Venezuelas feared SEBIN intelligence agency, said it was now time to rebuilt the country.He added: The hour has arrived for us to look for other ways of doing politics.To build the homeland our children and grandchildren deserve.Governments from around the world expressed support for Guaido while repeating calls to avoid violence.US National Security Adviser John Bolton said the Trump administration had received assurances from three key Maduro officials that the president would be removed peacefully.Mr Bolton declined to discuss possible military actions - but said that all options are on the table as President Trump monitors developments minute by minute.President Trump had tweeted: I am monitoring the situation in Venezuela very closely.The United States stands with the People of Venezuela and their Freedom!The uprising has been fuelled by popular resentment at political corruption in the country still wracked with poverty despite it having the worlds largest oil reserves.When oil prices crashed in , the Venezuelan government had not used the prosperous years to build up reserves to fall back on.Large areas of the collapsing country have been left in the dark for days at a time by power outages.More than three million Venezuelans have fled in recent years.Maduro has strongly resisted calls for an early vote or that he leave power early before his six-year second term ends in , sparking huge anti-government demonstrations.Venezuelas socialist party boss, Diosdado Cabello, called on government supporters to amass at the presidential palace to defend Maduro from what he called a small uprising of traitorous military soldiers backed by the US.He desperately tried to downplay the signicance of the rebellion, saying Caracas is calm and that the air base near where the rebellious soldiers are gathered had not been touched.Cabello said the opposition had not been able to take over the air base, which he said remained absolutely under the operational control of the government.Meanwhile supporters of UK Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn — a vocal admirer of the embattled socialist regime — dubbed the uprising a Pincohet-style coup.Corbynista MP Chris Williamson said: It appears that the USA is ramping up its efforts to overthrow the legitimate and democratically elected President of Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, in a military coup.I stand in full solidarity with the people of Venezuela against this attack on their democracy and sovereignty.The middle ranks are earning around  to  a month, and that is impacting their own structure, said one expert on Venezuelas armed forces.The military has also struggled to maintain its equipment as it suffers from a shortage of spare parts.According to some analysts, intelligence agents are also embedded among the military forces to guard against anti-regime activity.Those troops  who support the opposition have been accused of betrayal and have been arrested, according to Human Rights Watch.Authorities have also arrested the family members of some suspects in an effort to determine their whereabouts, the rights group said.Guaido, the leader of Venezuelas opposition-controlled National Assembly, in January invoked the constitution to assume an interim presidency.He argued that Maduros re-election in  was illegitimate.Around  countries including the United States have recognised Guaido as Venezuelas interim president.Maduro calls Guaido a US-backed puppet who seeks to oust him in a coup.The government has arrested his top aide, stripped Guaido of his parliamentary immunity and barred him from leaving the countryLast week, Guaido said his congressional ally - opposition lawmaker Gilber Caro - had been detained, and that  members of his team had been summoned to appear before the Sebin intelligence agency.

title: mum swindled 70k from employer disneyworld
story: Charlotte Clton, , doctored payments to suppliers and staff to fund the holiday, as well as meals out and her beautician course.She wept in the dock as she was handed a -month sentence, which the judge said she would serve at least six months of behind bars.The mum-of-three was accounts manager at County Gates Ltd, a small business based in Stockport that provides custom gates, railings, balconies and other metalwork.She was responsible for paying weekly wages to staff and suppliers, Minshull Street Crown Court heard.Before Christmas  a routine check of payments was carried out before the firm closed for the holidays.It was discovered that one payment went into Cltons account instead of to suppliers, according to Manchester Evening News.A company investigation then found that there were  fraudulent transactions disguised as payments to staff and suppliers.The sum of the money was £,, which the judge said the small firm could ill afford.She used some of the money to become qualied in doing non-surgical cosmetic procedures, which allowed her to set up shop as a self-employed beautician.Huw Edwards, defending, said she made the first few payments because of her dire financial position but became greedy when she got away with it.He urged the judge not to send her straight to prison.Mr Edwards said Clton, who has no previous convictions and three children, was genuinely remorseful for her actions and would be greatly affectedshe was jailed.Nicholas Clarke QC, told her that her -month sentence could not be suspended.He said: You indulged yourself at the expense of your employer, who trusted you explicitly.As accounts manager you were responsible for paying suppliers and staff wages. This offence was sophisticated and involved the altering of records.It was devious and quite deliberate.The total amount is signicant, over £,, which small family firms can ill-afford.There is a perception that fraud is a faceless crime but this case is a good example that most certainly is not.The company told police: Charlotte was a well-liked and trusted member of staff.We are shocked at the level of deception Charlotte has shown herself capable of.We had concerns because although we were busy and had plenty of customers, we were only making a minimal profit. Charlotte knew that we were cutting back.Despite this, she has continued to take from us.A Proceeds of Crime Acthearing will be held at a later date to begin to try and reclaim the money.

title: victory sun ms rethinks vegetarian percy pigs recipe
story: The Sun’s revelation yesterday that MS had sneakily turned the sweets vegetarian by removing gelatine prompted a huge reaction on social media.Analysis of the tens of thousands of posts on Facebook and Twitter showed the nation was split — with  per cent in favour,  per cent against and  per cent on the fence.Did you think this was going to cause such a big fuss Turns out it’s quite a pig deal! It’s split the nation’s opinion – we’ve had a big trotters up from some people but not everyone agrees...What did you think of Piers’s comments Piers really got his tail in a spin, but he didn’t need to spit it out! Given he’s such a big fan of the classic Percy, rather than s-whining, perhaps he’d like to join our Percy Pig .Are you enjoying being in the spotlight To be honest I’ve got used to the fame over the last  years. I’ve got some big celeb fans like Amanda Holden, Andy Murray, Calvin Harris and Lewis Hamilton, gate crashed the arrival of Prince George and have been on Britain’s Got Talent. Some of my mega fans have even got Percy tattoos, it’s always a bit awkward when you meet them...What are you going to do now Some customers aren’t happy...It’s all about the fans! We’re recruiting  of my super fans to form a Percy Pig  and vote on whether MS should introduce a special pack of classic Percy pigs with the gelatine back in.Can anyone join the  Yes - fans should trot over to the MS Facebook page to pitch for their place on the . They’ll need to share why they love Percy. As a family we’ve been hogging the limelight at MS for some time, but we didn’t predict this would be quite a pig deal.Removing animal product gelatine has made them veggie-friendly — but many fans say the best-selling sweets now taste like washing up liquid.MS will today announce a  of  Percy fans will meet on May  to discuss and vote on the sweet’s future.The main option is to bring back packs of the original recipe and sell them alongside the new veggie-friendly option.An MS spokesman said: “The Sun’s front page got the nation’s Percy fans debating and we want to hear what they have to say.“So we’re recruiting a  of  Percy mega fans to come to Percy HQ to decide on whether we should bring in a special edition - classic Percy pack with the gelatine in.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may jeremy corbyn customs union brexit deal
story: The PM dropped big hints on the potential compromise plan during a grilling from senior MPs yesterday.Sources close to the talks also revealed the proposal would let Britain sign limited free trade deals with other countries, probably only on services such as banking or insurance.At the same time, it would also allow frictionless trade in goods with the EU to continue by abiding by all Brussels’ customs rules.Cabinet ministers on Mrs May’s negotiating team are insistent that the cross-party agreement must be seen to preserve some element of an independent trade policy or they fear it won’t win the support of enough Tory MPs.The plan will be dubbed a customs “arrangement” rather than a customs union in a bid to detoxy it with Brexiteers.But while the two party leaders have committed to try to make it work, it is not yet clear whether either will be able to sell the fledgling deal to their respective wider Cabinets.Mrs May told MPs yesterday that the Tory and Labour teams’ thinking on the key issue was aligning, saying: “Actually, we are trying to achieve something very similar, which is trying to protect jobs”.The PM also revealed that work by the Tory and Labour negotiators was underway to draw up a new customs plan.She told the Liaison Committee of Commons chairmen: “One of the problems with this debate has consistently been that very often it is framed in terms of existing models. It is important for us to be looking at the new models that are available.“It’s also all too often framed in terms of existing language which people take to mean certain things.“Often people will use the terms customs union and have in their mind dferent things about what that achieves.”Mrs May added: “We are sitting down and talking about what both sides both want to achieve in relation to customs.“Can we come to an agreement on that  I hope we will, but those discussions continue.”In a unique display of cross-party Brexit unity, Labour chiefs reinforced Mrs May’s words last night to suggest a customs compromise was in the offing.Mr Corbyn’s spokesman said: “There is more than one way to skin a cat in terms of the Government moving off its position on a customs union.“The name isn’t the most important thing.”During the  minute session with the MPs, the PM also clashed with both Remainer and Brexiteer critics.Arch Tory Eurosceptic Sir Bill Cash told her: “You’ve just said you want to leave the EU. Well why don’t you get on with it Prime Minister ”Mrs May hit back: “”I’ve been trying to get on with it.“I want us to leave the European Union. I have been working for us to leave the European Union.“I have voted three times for it. If everyone across the House of Commons had voted the way I did, we would no longer be a member of the European Union”.Labour Home Affairs Committee boss Yvette Cooper also attacked Mrs May to say: “Resilience is a strength, but stubbornness is a weakness. What’s the evidence that you’re actually prepared to compromise ”Mrs May also conceded that the ongoing Brexit delay was hurting the economy, admitting that “uncertainty of any sort has an impact on business”.But she refused to put a date on when she will bring her orce deal back to the Commons for a fourth vote, saying only it would be “well before” the latest Article  extension’s end date of October .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits ordered to replace gas boilers switch to electric cars and use less beef lamb and dairy in 80bn plan to save planet
story: A Committee on Climate Change called for a dramatic upheaval of daily le as it urged Ministers to lead the world – and make the UK ‘net zero’ or ‘carbon neutral’ by .Committee chair Lord Deben said people should limit thermostats to  degrees and they should be forced to buy electric cars from  - ten years ahead of current Government plans.The peer – famed for feeding his daughter a burger in the BSE crisis – added that Brits should slash the amount of beef, lamb and dairy they eat by at least a FIFTH.And he called for Brits to take the train to Europe as well as “minimising” long haul flights.He even called for people to share power drills.Speaking to The Sun he said: “I’m not a puritan, I want everyone to enjoy their lives but think a little bit more about what they could do.“We can all see that the climate is changing and it needs a serious response.”Going ‘net zero’ will cost an estimated £ billion a year by  as Government is forced to invest in renewable technology, , more offshore wind turbines and building , charging points for electric vehicles.The Committee also wants to triple the rate of tree planting.But the peer insisted the cost was “manageable” and called on the Treasury to conduct a review into how low-income Brits could be protected from the mammoth bill.He conceded the UK was responsible for just  per cent of global emissions – but said it was a chance for the UK to take a lead.On Wednesday night, Business Secretary Greg Clark gave a cautious response to the plans.He said: “This report now sets us on a path to become the first major economy to legislate to end our contribution to global warming entirely.”But he refused to say when the Government would accept the recommendations.Charities on Wednesday night warned a limit of  degrees would put elderly Brits at “risk” in the depth of winter.There were , excess deaths in - because of the cold – the highest for  years.Caroline Abrahams, charity director at Age UK said: “Tackling the problem of climate change should be a top national and international priority.“But we need to pursue this in a way that does not inadvertently put the health of older people at risk.“The best medical advice is that older people should keep their living room temperature at  degrees to stay fit and well through the winter.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: john bercow first time stand down commons speaker
story: The controversial figure said he wouldn’t stay “much longer” in the influential role as arbiter of the Commons.He told his local constituency newspaper the Buckingham and Winslow Advertiser:If Theresa May can take a few weeks to change her mind about holding an election I can be forgiven for taking a few years to change my mind about staying on.It is the first time he has publicly commented on his future since breaking his pledge to stand down by June last year.When he stood to be Speaker in  he promised only to serve for nine years but he has justied staying on longer because of the uncertainty caused by Brexit.There is speculation that Mr Bercow could announce his departure date before the summer recess date, which starts in July.A spokesman for Mr Bercow said on Wednesday night: “The Speaker was elected by the House in  for the course of the Parliament. title: formula predict tubby by age ten
story: Experts analysed data on nearly , Dutch kids to create the new tubby risk calculator.They found  simple factors – such as birth weight, early growth and parental health - can help correctly forecast whether a child would later become overweight.Scientists claim the tool is  per cent precise and can be used within months of birth.All kids in England are measured when they begin primary school to assess whether they are overweight or obese.But researchers warn officials are intervening too late – and called for much earlier action.The findings were presented at the world’s largest obesity conference.Lead researcher Tanja Vrijkotte, Associate Professor Amsterdam Medical Center, said: “You can predict overweight at a very young ageyou combine early growth parameters with demographics, then you have a really good picture of the risk group.”One in three UK kids now leaves primary school overweight or obese.Being too heavy raises the risk of type  diabetes, heart and liver disease, and several common cancers.Tam Fry, from the National Obesity Forum, welcomed the tool. He said: “This can act as a wake up call to ensure that children can be set on the right road, with healthier habits.”Other key predictors are diabetes and smoking during pregnancy, and whether the child’s parents are also fat.Prof Vrijkotte hopes the test will help medics identy children at higher risk so they can act early to prevent poor health.She said many parents would be shocked by the tool’s predictions.Speaking at the European Congress on Obesity in Glasgow, she added: “It is so dficult to lose weight so I think we should focus on prevention, so that children can become healthy adults.“I think we should start earlier than two years old... to use these kinds of tools in discussing with the parents, when the infant does not have a problem yet.”CHATTY parents are more likely to have brainier kids with larger vocabularies, a study found.Tots exposed to more adult words aged two to four performed better in thinking, numeracy and shape awareness tests.They also used a greater iety of words themselves.Researchers fitted tiny sound recorders into the clothing of  pre-school children and monitored them at home for three days.Mums, dads and other carers also completed activities with the kids, such as drawing, copying and matching tasks.Analysis revealed children with the most talkative parents scored highest.Those who were encouraged to explore and express themselves were also less likely to be restless, aggressive and disobedient.Study leader Katrina d’Apice, from the University of York, said recording the children at home gave better results than previous lab-based tests.She added: “We found that the quantity of adult spoken words that children hear is positively associated with their cognitive ability.“However, further research is needed to explore the reasons behind this link.“It could be that greater exposure to language provides more learning opportunities for children.“But it could also be the case that more intelligent children evoke more words from adults in their environment.”Prof Sophie von Stumm, who also worked on the study, said: “This study is the largest naturalistic observation of early le home environments to date.“We found that the quantity of adult spoken words that children were exposed to ied greatly within families.“Some kids heard twice as many words on one day as they did on the next.”The findings are published in the journal Developmental Psychology.Possible interventions include diet changes or more exercise to reduce their obesity risk.Commenting on the study Dr Max Davie, Officer for Health Improvement at the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, said: “Any model that accurately predicts an increased likelihood of developing obesity allows us to intervene and provide targeted weight management support and advice at an earlier stage.“We know that overweight children are more likely to become overweight adults with an increased risk of serious health problems, so being able to identy and help young children at risk would go some way towards protecting their health in the future.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: penny mordaunt appointed britains first female defence secretary
story: The popular, plain-speaking Brexiteer was an obvious fit for the job given she is a Royal Navy reservist, holding the rank of sub-lieutenant. Her last deployment to sea was in .She is the daughter of a former paratrooper and she was even named after the Leander-class frigate HMS Penelope - which played a key role in defeating the Argentines in the Falklands War.Penny, , also represents a constituency packed with service voters in Portsmouth North.She has enjoyed a steady rise up the pecking order and will move to the Ministry of Defence after  months in charge of Britain’s bloated £ billion a year foreign aid budget, where her main challenge was dealing with the fallout from the Oxfam sex scandal.And her latest promotion will propel the ambitious minister’s chances of reaching the very top.Ms Mordaunt had a dficult upbringing after her mother died of breast cancer when she was .The same year her father was diagnosed with cancer - leaving her and her twin brother to care for their younger brother.She paid her way through college by taking a job as a magician’s assistant, which involved her being ‘sawn in half’.Penny enjoyed a colourful time as a backbench MP - and first won notoriety outside the House of Commons for being on reality TV ing show Splash!.Despite an early KO for a spectacular belly flop, her pluck won her respect from fellow MPs and constituents after she gave her £, appearance fee to local and military charities.At Westminster, three years ago Penny became only the second woman to propose the loyal address after the Queen’s Speech — and the first to talk balls.She had MPs in stitches recalling the time on her naval training she was part of a course on caring for her “penis and testicles”.“Fascinating though it was,” she said, “I felt the lecture and practical demonstration failed to appreciate some of us were issued with the incorrect kit.”But her use of colourful language came back to bite her when she confessed to saying “cock” six times and “lay” or “laid” five times in a Commons debate to win a bet with Navy friends.David Cameron promoted Penny into the Government in , making her first a Local Government minister and then an Armed Forces minister — which she called her dream job. Theresa May moved her to Minister for the Disabled when she became PM.Passionate Brexiteer Penny has committed one major political gaffe, when she wrongly claimed Britain would not be able to veto Turkey joining the EU, which got her a furious dressing-down from then boss Mr Cameron.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: local elections 2019 they council
story: NewsLocal elections : When are they, council candidates and results predictionsAfter months of Brexit chaos, finally millions of Brits are getting to cast their vote in the  council elections. Heres everything you need to knowShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY NewsFinally, a chance to think about something that isnt Brexit "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit has consumed British politics for months. But thereaposs a major event on May  that affects you more powerfully and directly than leaving the EU. They are the local elections - where millions of voters across England get to decide who oversees their parks, streets, libraries, leisure centres and more. More than , seats are up for grabs, half of them Conservative, which means Theresa Mayaposs party has a huge amount to lose. Tory peer and pollster Robert Hayward has claimed the party could lose  seats, around a fth of all those up for grabs. So when are the elections and what are the areas to look out for  Hereaposs everything you need to know, or you can see hour-by-hour results declaration times here.  The  local elections are being held on Thursday  May. Polls open at am and close at pm. Around half of councilsapos results are being counted overnight, with results expected from midnight. The other half will start being counted on Friday morning so results can be expected to pour in after lunch. Where are the  local elections being held   Council elections are being held in most of England outside London and Birmingham. Some  town, city, borough and county halls have seats up for grabs - ranging from a third of the council to every single seat. In total  unitary councils,  metropolitan boroughs and  non-metropolitan districts are taking part. There are also elections for six directly-elected mayors - in Bedford, Copeland, Leicester, Mansfield, Middlesbrough and North of Tyne. Elections are not taking place in Scotland or Wales, or big unitary authorities like Cornwall, Wiltshire, Northumbria, Durham and Shropshire, or parts of Cambridgeshire. When was the register to vote deadline   Voters had to register by midnight on Friday  April on the governmentaposs website. In addition, anyone wanting to vote by post had to register for a postal ballot by pm on Monday  April. Those wanting to vote by proxy - where you send someone to vote in your place - had to apply by pm on Wednesday  April. Registered voters have until pm on polling day to apply for an emergency proxy votethey are hit by unforeseen circumstances. How do I checkIaposm registered to vote   Every local authority holds the electoral register for their own area. There is no online electoral roll. To checkyou are registered to vote, you will need to contact your local electoral registration office. See the full list on the Your Vote Matters website. Who are the candidates in my area   You can find out which council, and which ward, you are in by visiting the Who Can I Vote For website and entering your postcode. It will then tell youthere are elections in your ward for local councillors. There should also be list of all the candidates standing for election in your area and what party they represent.  How many seats are up for grabs   , seats are up for grabs, according to research by Tory polling guru Lord Hayward. . Just over halfthe seats are Conservative, according to new analysis by Lord Hayward and polling firm ComRes. Likewise, more than half the councils up for grabsare Tory-controlled, according to the Local Government Information Unit. Labour is defending just , seats while Lib Dems hold , Independents hold  and  seats belong to smaller parties or community groups. Labour controls  councils, while seven are in Lib Dem hands and  are under no overall control. Five are new councils. Who will aposwinapos the local elections   The Tories will technically win - get the most seats - because they currently hold around half the ,-odd council seats up for grabs. Thataposs because this yearaposs elections are focused on more rural areas that are Tory strongholds. But that huge total means the Tories have the most to lose from low turnout and voters frustrated by Brexit . And matters could be made worse by the fact that the last elections of this kind were in  - a high point for the Tories when they unexpectedly won the general election on the same day. Tory peer and pollster Robert Hayward has predicted the Tories could lose  seats while the Lib Dems pick up  and Labour claw back .    Ashfield was Labour until a slew of defections last year to Independents and Tories. Will it tip back  Thanet was once UKIPaposs stronghold and aposIndependent and UKIPapos are the second-largest grouping. Tories hold the administration and should gainBrexitaposs going well. Or the vote could go to anti-establishment parties. Lib Dems are tipped to make gains in Bath and North East Somerset and Wokingham - home to hard Brexiteer Tory MPs Jacob Rees-Mogg and John Redwood. Labour need a small change to seize control of Trafford and Calderdale councils, among the handful of metropolitan areas Jeremy Corbynaposs party doesnapost control. But Tories are standing candidates in every seat in every metropolitan authority, so theyaposll put up a fight. Itaposs a tougher battle in neck-and-neck red-blue battlegrounds Carlisle and Brighton. Dudley has a minority Labour administration but only on a kne-edge, and a small change could tip it back to the Tories. Walsall and Stoke-on-Trent on a kne-edge the other way round, with only a small change needed for Labour to come out on top. Labour also only need a small boost in Derby to gain control from an unusual pairing of Tories, Lib Dems and UKIP, But Labour had big losses last year and itaposs one of  councils where UKIP are putting up a full slate of candidates. Labour only needs a little gain in Redcar and Cleveland to get overall control. And the Tories need just one extra seat to gain control in Scarborough and Teignbridge - or two in Thurrock. Any signs of an anti-Brexit effect could come in Stockport, a minority Labour council with a big Lib Dem contingent. And Tories appear worried about Theresa Mayaposs image in Cheshire East and Wirral, where you can find some standing under a aposlocal Conservativesapos ticket. Maidstone is a Lib Dem-Tory battleground, with the yellows in power but the blues needing four gains to seize control. So is Winchester, where the Lib Dems are just one seat behind the Tories, and North Norfolk and Portsmouth. Some councils are narrowly held so could be thrown into no overall control with just a slight change. They include Cannock Chase , Three Rivers and South Somersetand Mole Valley, Tandridge, Pendle and Woking . And the Tories could lose overall control in Hertfordshire or Peterboroughtheyaposre having a bad night. Meanwhile some rock-solid councils will be worth watching. Tories are defending  of  seats in Amber Valley, so this will be target practice for rivals. The Greens are hopeful in Stratford-upon-Avon where theyaposre putting up a full slate of candidates. Leeds has  dferent political groups standing - the most of any area. But not everyone has to fight for survival.  seats are unopposed or guaranteed in Fenland. What will the results mean for the main parties   The huge number of Tory seats means the elections will be target practice on Tories, polling guru Lord Hayward said. The party is widely expected to lose ground no matter what happens, but how much ground will be a test of Theresa Mayaposs leadership. Labour could be expected to gain seats, because the last election for these seats was on general election day in , but not necessarily. The picture may be more complicated. Turnout is set to drop “dramatically” since the seats were last fought in , and that could hit both main parties and establishment groups hard. Despite soaring membership under Jeremy Corbyn , Labour is contesting just % of all seats. This is a rise from % in  and % in , but well below the % contested by Tories. A Labour source said it was because many of the elections are being held in rural Tory heartlands. The Lib Dems are contesting % of seats and are widely expected to have a bounce back, while the Greens are contesting % of all. UKIP are contesting just % of all seats, a dramatic drop from % in . The party can expect a wipeout. How will Brexit affect the elections   No one knows for sure - but experts think continued chaos and indecision would hit the Tories hard. Tory peer Lord Hayward warned Conservatives across England face losing their council seats in a “ Brexit penalty”thereaposs still no deal.  Lord Hayward said the drop in turnout, combined with “bored to the teeth” Brexit voters staying at home, is set to hit the Conservatives in their heartlandsthere is still no agreement in a month’s time.  The peer - who predicted the “shy Tories” surge that helped David Cameron win in  - said: “There is a Brexit benefit to the governmentthere is a deal.  “There is clearly a disadvantage, disbenefit, a deficit to the Tory party to not having a deal. “There’s no question about it. Andyou talk to most of the MPs they will say exactly the same thing.” Lord Haywardaposs analysis claimed Lib Dems and Greens were most likely to benefit from any Tory losses. What about boundary changes  A huge number of councils have changed their seat boundaries or re-formed into new councils entirely since . This makes like-for-like comparisons of results very dficult. According to the Press Association, councils with confirmed local boundary changes coming into effect for the May  polls are:Unitary authorities: Bath  North East Somerset, Cheshire West  Chester, Nottingham, Redcar  Cleveland, Rutland, South Gloucestershire, Torbay, West Berkshire, Windsor  Maidenhead Royal politan boroughs: none. Non-met authorities: Allerdale, Ashford, Babergh, Bolsover, Carlisle, Chichester, Copeland, Crawley, Dartford, Dover, East Cambridgeshire, East Devon, East Hampshire, Eastbourne, Forest of Dean, Harborough, Hertsmere, Horsham, King’s Lynn  West Norfolk, Lewes, Mid Suffolk, North East Derbyshire, North Norfolk, Norwich, Preston, Reigate  Banstead, Ribble Valley, Richmondshire, Rother, Runnymede, Scarborough, South Norfolk, South Somerset, Surrey Heath, Teignbridge, Tendring, Test Valley, Tewkesbury, Torridge, Warwick, Wealden.In addition, owing to local authority mergers, there are several new councils in the  local elections, replacing existing councils. The changes are as follows:Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole go into a single Bournemouth, Christchurch  Poole unitary authority East Dorset, North Dorset, Purbeck, West Dorset and Weymouth  Portland, as well as Dorset County Council, go into DorsetSuffolk Coastal and Waveney become East SuffolkForest Heath and St Edmundsbury become West SuffolkTaunton Deane and West Somerset become Somerset West  Taunton .

story: NewsLocal elections: Corbyn slams bickering Tories as they face -seat wipeoutJeremy Corbyn has accused the Theresa May government of bickering while the public suffers at the hands of austerityShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsTheresa May is set to have yet another bad week "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tories are on the brink of a local election meltdown tomorrow as voters go to the polls across the country.  Theresa May’s party could lose around  council seats inflicting further misery on the already battered Conservatives.  And the Prime Minister knows a disastrous day at the polls could hasten her departure.   Her only silver lining is that Nigel Farage’s Brexit party is not standing and UKIP is only putting up candidates in one in six seats. Speaking to the Mirror, Jeremy Corbyn accused ministers of “bickering and jostling” while the country suffered from austerity.  “People don’t feel like what’s going on in Westminster has any bearing on their lives,” he said.    Voters are desperately concerned by the social care crisis, rising crime, the plight of high streets and school cuts. But Mr Corbyn added: “In their front rooms TVs have blared about the mess Theresa May has made of the Brexit negotiations and plots to depose her.” The Labour leader is hoping to show the momentum is with his party by clocking up over  gains.  But he acknowledged that the elections could be “tough” for Labour too with Brexit “overshadowing” everything. And party insiders suggested polling expertsapos predictions the Tories could lose more than  seats were “way off”.  This set of elections were last fought on the day of the  general election, when turn-out was high and David Cameron won a small majority.    A lower turnout nearly always disproportionately hits the Labour vote. The elections are also predominantly in Leave-voting Tory heartlands that could punish Labour over its second referendum stance.   In a plea to voters, Mr Corbyn said: “Today people have the chance to elect caring and hardworking Labour councillors and mayors to show Theresa May and the Conservatives that after nine years of running down and cutting vital services, there is an alternative.” Some , seats are up for grabs in  councils in England. The Tories defend ,, Labour , and the Lib Dems . Labour hopes to seize Trafford, Redcar and Calderdale and leapfrog the Tories as Brighton’s biggest party.  A good night would result in the party winning Walsall, Stoke-on-Trent and Derby. Any signs of an anti-Brexit effect could come in Stockport, a minority Labour council with a big Lib Dem contingent.

And they were published too late for , ex-Tax Credit claimants who have already been moved onto UC through a change in circumstances.  Mr Sharma claimed the Department for Work and Pensionsmade a mistake in withholding the report from the public for more than a year. Today UC Director-General Neil Couling admitted the date could not be brought forward any earlier. He said his team was full of mechanics with their hands in the engine, attempting to move claimants off IT systems conceived in the late s and built in the s. He described UC as the biggest digital development in Western Europe - and warned that once aposmanaged migrationapos begins, it will happen at breakneck speed. He told MPs: “The reason why it’s tricky and I’ve asked for the time to do this to the middle of  is because you go straight to a high volume. “As soon as we switch it on, in that week the run-ons will apply to ,-odd cases. So we’ve really got to get that right.”

story: NewsDevious mum-of-three nicked £k from employer to take kids to DisneyworldCharlotte Clton, swindled her bosses at County Gates Ltd by disguising payments to herself worth tens of thousands of poundsShareCommentsByChris Slater:,  MAY NewsCharlotte Clton will serve at least six months behind bars for her deception "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA aposdevious and greedyapos mum swindled £, from her employer to take her kids on a trip to Disneyworld. Mother-of-three Charlotte Clton doctored payments to suppliers and staff to funnel tens of thousands of pounds into her own account.Clton wept in the dock as the judge told her she would serve at least six months behind bars for her deception, reports the Manchester Evening News.The -year-old worked as accounts manager at County Gates Ltd, a small business based at Chadkirk Industrial estate in Romiley, Stockport, that provides custom gates, railings, balconies and other metalwork. She was responsible for paying suppliers and the weekly staff wages, Minshull Street Crown Court heard. In December , a routine check of payments was carried out before the firm closed for Christmas. It was discovered that the bank account details on one payment were not that of the supplier, but Cltonaposs.    A more detailed examination revealed  fraudulent transactions disguised as wages payments or payments to suppliers. The total amount of money funnelled out of the company was said to be over £,, a sum a judge said companies of that size could aposill affordapos. Police said Clton used to the money to obtain qualications for non-surgical cosmetic procedures, which have enabled her to start up her own business as a self-employed beautician. She also spent the money on days out, eating out and even booked a family holiday to Disneyworld in the US, they added. Clton, of Dorking Close, Stockport, admitted one count of fraud at an earlier hearing. Huw Edwards, defending, said Clton made the first few payments due to her then aposdire financial positionapos, but because she aposgot away with itapos, she aposbecame greedyapos and carried on taking money, which she began to rely on. He said Clton, who has no previous convictions, was aposgenuinely remorsefulapos and urged the judge not to send her straight to prison. Mr Edwards said Clton has three children, who would be greatly affectedshe was jailed. I cannot think of a more worthy candidate to have her sentence suspended, her offending behaviour aside, he added. Clton wept in the dock as the judge, Recorder Nicholas Clarke QC, told her a -month sentence could not be suspended. She will serve half her sentence in prison and the rest on licence. He told her: You indulged yourself at the expense of your employer, who trusted you explicitly. As accounts manager you were responsible for paying suppliers and staff wages. This offence was sophisticated and involved the altering of records.    It was devious and quite deliberate. The total amount is signicant, over £,, which small family firms can ill-afford. There is a perception that fraud is a faceless crime but this case is a good example that most certainly is not. The company told police: Charlotte was a well-liked and trusted member of staff. We are shocked at the level of deception Charlotte has shown herself capable of. We had concerns because although we were busy and had plenty of customers, we were only making a minimal profit. Charlotte knew that we were cutting back. Despite this, she has continued to take from us. A Proceeds of Crime Acthearing will be held at a later date to begin to try and reclaim the money.

Remarkably, Kate not only did it with her firstborn, but then again with Charlotte and Louis.While a lot was obviously made of her changing style and the subtle nods to Diana , another change was playing out before our eyes. If you look back at Kateon the famous Lindo Wing steps with each of her babies, other dferences in how she handled the publicity become more apparent too. Prince George With so many new royal babies having made their debut - or about to - Georgeaposs birth on  July seems like a letime ago. Just a day after his birth, the new parents faced the press and the public outside the Lindo Wing.  The couple had delayed announcing the birth for four hours as theyaposd wanted to just enjoy spending some time with their tiny son first. When they eventually tottered outside, they were very generous with their time in the front of the cameras. Out of all of their children, William and Kate spent the longest posing for photos with George. As for why, there are a number of potential reasons.  It was a warm summer evening. George will be king one day, meaning public interest was particularly high. And, as elated, emotional, first-timers, they may have felt more inclined to show their baby off. Dressed in a polkadot Jenny Packham number, Kate did not try to hide her postpartum tummy. She paired the dress with some casual cork wedges and wore her hair in a natural, loose style.There were some signs of nerves from the new parents .Kate kept a firm hold on George, cradling him with both arms during their appearance. Only once did she release one hand to wave for photos.  Onlookers also witness a sweet and slightly fumbling handover as Kate passed George to William - and then there was the struggle fitting the car seat, which any parent can relate to. Kateaposs body language also gave away her nerves.Kateaposs feet are nearly overlapping as sheaposs standing on the stairs, body language expert Patti Wood told Good Housekeeping .This indicates that she feels the need to keep it all together. Both of them have relaxed hands but thereaposs slight gestures like the feet and forced smiles that indicate theyaposre a bit tense in this moment.    And who could blame them  Princess Charlotte Just under two years later and William and Kate are no longer first-time parents working through all the nerves and novelty of having a newborn. Kate was admitted to hospital in the early hours of the morning on May , and left later that evening.    The couple once again posed for photos but there was a marked dference from the photocall with George. Not only did Kate seem a lot more polished and preened , but she seemed a lot more confident too.    This tender moment between Will and Kate is something out of a movie, Wood said. Her fingers are locked inside his, which is her subtle way of saying aposthis moment is all about us.apos  This time, she and William spent less than two minutes in front of the camera. There was no answering questions of walkabout as there had been with George, and Kate kept hold of Charlotte the whole time - albeit cradling her with just one arm. They both appeared more poised and comfortable - and a little more businesslike.    William, this time, bossed fitting the car seat - and he even flashed a cheeky peace sign at the waiting paps. Prince Louis By the time baby Louis arrived, the Cambridges were seasoned pros at parenting - and their appearance outside the Lindo Wing proved it. There was a smaller crowd gathered outside this time - perhaps because the little prince falls slightly further down the royal ranking.  Kate was ready to face the cameras just seven hours after giving birth, and looked even more cofed, once again wearing Jenny Packham and in high heels. Perhaps mindful of the cool wind and their two eldest waiting for them at home, she and William spent just a minute and a half outside. One particularly touching shot of Kate and her new son shows them mirroring eachothersapos hand gestures.    Sure, Kate is fixing her hair from the wind but itaposs also an indicator of a strong rapport between the two, Susan Constantine, human behavioral expert and author tells Good Housekeeping. After some brief posing, the couple marched over to their car - completely confident and in sync.

story: NewsInside unique charity where Britains top chefs serve lavish meals to homelessEXCLUSIVE: The St Cuthbert’s Centre in Kensington, London, is a charity where volunteers provide nutritional high-class meals for rough sleepers and vulnerable peopleShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsChefs from the Fat Duck group Edward Cooke, Tom Allen, Jonny Glass and Daniel Svensson "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Britainaposs top chefs - including a team from Heston Blumenthalaposs The Fat Duck - are regularly cooking lavish three-course meals for homeless people at a unique charity. The St Cuthbert’s Centre in west London provides a fine-dining experience for rough sleepers and other vulnerable members of the community five days a week.Those who attend are left amazed at the standard of the food with many left saying aposthereaposs nowhere  like itapos and apositaposs one of the best places Iaposve ever eatenapos. The open door service, known as Refettorio Felix and under the umbrella of non-profit organisation Food for Soul, is run by an amazing team of dedicated staff and volunteers. They cook up a delicious menu which changes every day and caters for inidual dietary requirements. Once a week, the centre has a aposguest chef takeoverapos - with famous names coming to prepare the food. A team from Heston Blumenthalaposs three Michelin star restaurant The Fat Duck are regulars who take control of the kitchen.  Brett Graham, head chef of the two Michelin star restaurant The Ledbury also pays a visit once every four weeks to cook up a special feast. Other well-known names who have offered their time and expertise are Executive Chef of the Ritz John Williams, who has cooked at the centre with his team, chefs from Harrods, and Jason Atherton who co-hosted the Sky Living TV series My Kitchen Rules in . And just like the regular staff at the centre, the top chefs have no idea what they will make until a van delivers fresh ingredients first thing in the morning, donated on a daily basis from a range of charities, supermarkets and restaurants working to minimise wasting surplus food. Most of the ingredients come from The Felix Project, which collects surplus food from food retailers and wholesalers and then redistributes it to charities and schools that provide food for those in need. But others are donated from Michelin star and popular restaurants, with everything on site made from scratch.  The Ledburyaposs Brett Graham said chefs are in a fortunate position to help charities.  He said: These people need a bit of nourishment, a lot of people are down on their luck. Itaposs about making a place where they feel normal. Some of the people who attend donapost have anyone to help them, no family or support. I want that place to feel special. I want people who use the service to feel like itaposs a treat and to feel like they are going to a restaurant. I enjoy cooking there and being part of it. I felt quite emotional on my first time there two years ago. Mr Graham helps out once a month but praised the work the regular staff do on a daily basis as aposfantasticapos saying: The chefs do a great job there every day and the volunteers are amazing.  About  per cent of people who turn up to St Cuthbertaposs are rough sleepers. The rest who attend are made up of the elderly, adults with learning dficulties and people with mental health conditions who live in the community but need help with caring for themselves. One woman who attends the centre, Rene, said: This is one of the best places I have eaten - I really appreciate their efforts. Russell, , has been homeless since , eating at dferent centres or waiting outside takeaways for them to throw out leftovers. He said nowhere  compares to the food at St Cuthbertaposs.  Thereaposs nothing I know of thataposs close to it for food, Russell said. Itaposs nice to be able to come and eat here and thereaposs far more people who would comethey knew about it than this place can even accomodate.  I heard about it through word of mouth - and this is what I found, he said. And he said the fine-dining experience was far from anywhere  heaposd been.    Russell said: I used to go to a day centre where everyone, like me, was homeless. But people would arrive there staggering drunk and it was the kind of place I didnapost want to be, so I had to stop. One of the problems I had to solve is, where do I get food  I regularly go to a carry out place when it closes at pm for leftovers. But anytime you find somewhere like that you have to be careful because before you know it thereaposll be others standing around doing the same. People say apossave for a rainy day,apos but what do you doevery day is a rainy day   Russell, who sleeps rough, said heaposd been in low paid jobs his whole le until he found himself out of employment and on the streets, with no savings.  I realised the alternative was ending my le or trying this le of being homeless, he said.  I donapost go to shelters because the people there are drug addicts or gamblers, they take peopleaposs things.  There are rules and regulations of shelters but I like my freedom.  If I can find a safe, quiet place to sleep, I would rather not get someone aposs permission. One man, who has been homeless for  years and did not want to be named, said: We get free food here and nice chefs who are kind. I can sit down calmly and have my food served to me. Here is a list of some of the guest chefs who have visited the charity: * Fat Duck group chefs Edward Cooke,Tom Allen, Jonny Glass and Daniel Svensson * Brett Graham, head chef of the two Michelin star restaurant The Ledbury * Executive Chef of the Ritz, John Williams * Greg Marchand, whose restaurant Frenchie Rue du Nil in Paris has been awarded a Michelin star * Sally Abé who is the head chef at Michelin-starred The Harwood Arms in London * Michelin-star chef Merlin Labron-Johnson * Chefs from Harrods * Jason Atherton who co-hosted the Sky Living TV series My Kitchen Rules in .   Jean Usher, , lives nearby and the centre enables her to have company and make great friends. We have lots of celebrity chefs here. We get a chef from the Ritz and Brett Graham from The Ledbury. Itaposs a great place to be, I wouldnapost want to be anywhere . Where would I go  I would be sitting in my one-bed flat feeling sorry for myself. Here we get a dferent menu every day. Fidela Orthega says she was once homeless for three weeks so she can relate to many people at the centre. A regular at St Cuthbertaposs for nine years, she said she is diabetic but her needs are catered for. Fidela, , said: This place is a home away from home. Steve, , added: I have got an awful lot of problems. I donapost like being on my own. Here I get my tea and a lovely lunch.  Examples of dishes Brett Graham has rustled up at the centre include veal T bones, pumpkin soup with ginger, chilli, turmeric, yoghurt and coriander and a iety of freshly made ice cream. This month chefs from The Fat Duck and Dinner by Heston attended the centre and the menu entailed a roasted vegetable salad with hummus and a pesto dressing to start, a choice of two curries for the main and a sticky toffee pudding to finish off. An example of a meal cooked by the centreaposs regular staff is a Morrocan-style white bean stew with pumkin and sesame with a pineapple carpaccio dessert.  The St Cuthbert’s Centre is a charity set up  years ago, but the Chief Executive said it was what you would expect a drop in centre to look like. It was around two years ago that the concept changed. They gets referrals from shelters and hospitals - but people mainly turn up after hearing about it through word of mouth. Chief Executive of St Cuthbertaposs Centre Ali Kingsley says: A lot of people helped by the centre are at crisis point, they are sleeping on the streets.  Itaposs all about giving them back their dignity, until they feel valued and that they are in a special place. He said for many who come to the centre, the three-course meal has to sustain them for  hours until they come back the next day. * Veal T bones * Pumpkin soup with ginger, chilli, turmeric, yoghurt and coriander * Morrocan-style white bean stew with pumkin and sesame * Moroccan-style chicken with spiced carrots, potatoes, leeks and cabbage * Hot smoked salmon fish pie with broccoli and green beans * Broccoli, caullower and courgette gratin with potatoes * Roasted vegetable salad with a hummus and a pesto dressing* Roast carrot and fennel soup with sunflower seeds * Sticky toffee pudding * Pineapple carpaccio with mint, sugar and a chocolate slice * Apple strudel * A iety of freshly made ice cream.   Two mental health support staff work at the centre - one a counsellor and the other a nutritional psychologist - and they can refer people to other services.Practical advice is offered to people on Universal Credit , and homeless people are helped with filling in forms and getting appointments with a doctor in some cases.The seating - long tables set out in the hall - is laid out to promote social interaction, a key element to what the centre does. About  people are fed the lunch each day, many are regulars but new faces are seen daily as well. Two staff chefs and four volunteer assistants make the food every day, when St Cuthbertaposs is not apostaken overapos by celebs. The centre also offers clubs for activities such as knitting and art. A barber comes in once a week to offer haircuts, clothes can be washed on site, and showers are available. Melissa, a volunteer, said she works at St Cuthbertaposs because, like many others who are involved in the initiative, I feel I want to give something back to the community.

title: loving dad 33 found hugging
story: NewsLoving dad, , found hugging photo of daughter after taking own leAndy Hamill, from Birkenhead, Wirral, took a cocktail of drugs after telling a friend he "didnt want to be here"ShareCommentsByRachael McMenemy:,  MAY NewsAndy had struggled with his mental health for a decade "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA devoted dad was found hugging a photo of his daughter after taking his own le, an inquest heard. Andy Hamill, a father-of-two, was found dead by police at his home on February  after consuming a cocktail of drugs. The -year-old from Birkenhead had struggled with his mental health for a decade and sent worrying messages and pictures to friends in the days before he died. The Liverpool FC fan has been described by the mother of his children, Rebecca Waldron, as a doting dad who had an incredibly close bond with his two children.She told the Liverpool Echo: He was so funny and witty and liked and heaposd always go the extra mile to help me and the kids out. Nothing was ever a problem.He always sent videos of the kids and was always in contact, we very much did things together and decided everything together.    She added: We were very much a family unit. He was a doting dad, he just had such a close bond with the kids, Iaposve never seen a dad have a bond like that with kids to be honest. Andy had battled with mental health problems since  and had previously attempted to take his own le, the hearing at Liverpool Coroneraposs Court heard. In the days and hours before his death, Andy sent messages and pictures to Rebecca, his ex-partner Hannah Gale and other friends which first sparked concern for his wellbeing three days before he was found.  On the Friday before he died on the Monday, he sent Rebecca a message saying he couldnapost look after the children the next day because he was in a bad place and apologised to her for being a failure, telling her her she was a great mum. On the same night he also sent a message to Hannah asking hershe could look after his daughter the next day because he wouldnapost be around. Protecting his children from his mental health dficulties became a main focus for Andy. Rebecca said: He always knew when he was ill and heaposd say he couldnapost have the kids or send me a message, like on the Friday - and say to leave them until he could calm himself down. Officers from Merseyside Police rushed to his home twice on Friday, February  when other friends raised concern for his well-being after he sent messages and shared pictures suggesting he may harm himself. However, on both occasions Andy told officers and paramedics that he was fine and there was no cause for concern. His family and friends repeatedly tried to reach out to him over the weekend but were largely unable to contact him.    He sent a last message to a friend on Saturday afternoon where he said he didnapost want to be here. That was the last time anyone had any direct contact with Andy. On Monday evening, police ed to his flat and found Andy hugging a picture of his daughter, having taken his own le. Assistant Coroner Joseph Hart concluded he had died as a result of suicide caused by taking a cocktail of drugs. Mr Hart said: Andy was found in a rear bedroom, laying on the bed and as I understand it from investigations, he was hugging a pillow with a picture of his daughter in his arms. Paramedics pronounced him dead at the scene shortly before pm. In delivering his verdict Mr Hart said: The heart of this seems very clear, on the balance of probabilities Andy Hamill took a quantity and combination of drugs, the effect of which was to cause his death. I have little dficulty in reaching that conclusion. I have to then go on and consider what he intended by taking these drugs. He added that it was clear Andy did not want help and effectively stonewalled any attempts to help him. Mr Hart said: Perhaps the clearest indicator for me of his actual intent is that a running theme through his mental health dficulties was the protective father being there for his children. Whilst profoundly upsetting, perhaps the most important piece of evidence is that when he is found he was hugging a photograph of his daughter. He demonstrated, in my view, evidence of his profound love of his children. After the inquest Rebecca urged others suffering with mental health dficulties to seek help and speak out when they are struggling.If youaposre struggling and need someone to speak to, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open   on  . Alternatively, you can email jo@samaritans.org or visit their website to find your local branch
